headline: CA Technologies, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the CA Technologies' Third Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference call is being recorded. I would now like to introduce your conference call for today's
componenttext: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the CA Technologies' Third Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference call is being recorded. I would now like to introduce your conference call for today's conference, Jonathan Doros. Sir, you may begin.

headline: CA Technologies, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, and good afternoon, everyone. Welcome to CA Technologies' Third Quarter Fiscal Year 2015 Earnings Call. Joining me today are Mike Gregoire, our Chief Executive Officer; and Rich Beckert, our Chief Financial Officer. Mike and Rich will offer som
componenttext:
Thank you, and good afternoon, everyone. Welcome to CA Technologies' Third Quarter Fiscal Year 2015 Earnings Call. Joining me today are Mike Gregoire, our Chief Executive Officer; and Rich Beckert, our Chief Financial Officer. Mike and Rich will offer some prepared remarks and then we will open up the call for Q&A session.
These prepared comments were previously recorded and this conference call is being broadcast on Tuesday, January 20, over the telephone and Internet. The information shared in this call is effective as of today's date and will not be updated. All content is the property of CA Technologies and is protected by U.S. and international copyright law and may not be reproduced are transcribed in any way without the expressed written consent of CA Technologies. We consider your continued participation in this call as a consent to our recording.
During this call, non-GAAP financial measures will be discussed. Reconciliations to most directly comparable GAAP financial measures are included in our earnings release, which is filed on Form 8-K earlier today, as well as in our supplemental earnings materials, all of which are available on our website, at ca.com/invest.
Our today's discussion will include forward-looking statements, subject to risks and uncertainties, and actual results could differ materially from these forward-looking statements. Please refer to our SEC filings for a detailed discussion of potential risk. Please note that our third quarter quiet period begins at the close of business on March 13, 2015. Let me remind you that all comparisons are year-over-year and in constant currency unless otherwise indicated. So with that, let me turn the call over to Mike.

headline: CA Technologies, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, and thank you for joining us. During the third quarter, we saw further evidence of the strategy we put in place is beginning to yield results. While total third quarter new sales declined approximately 10% year-over-year, this was mainly t
componenttext:
Good afternoon, and thank you for joining us. During the third quarter, we saw further evidence of the strategy we put in place is beginning to yield results. While total third quarter new sales declined approximately 10% year-over-year, this was mainly the result of a headwind from the timing of our renewable portfolio, which was down in the mid-30% range year-over-year. As a reminder, we faced a tough year-over-year comparison from a $300 million-plus transaction with a systems integrator that closed in the third quarter of fiscal 2014. As we have said in the past, a large percentage of our new sales are still attached to renewal opportunities.
Within Enterprise Solutions, we are beginning to see success in our strategy to seed accounts with smaller deals through the value of our software and expand our footprint with follow-on transactions. An impact on the smaller transactions size is near-term headwinds to the Enterprise Solutions' new sales growth. However, while our Enterprise new sales were below our expectations during the quarter, we are seeing a higher volume of transactions both during the quarter and year-to-date in our growth product solutions. This is creating beachheads with our named accounts, which is leading to additional follow-on pipeline for many of these solutions.
Turning to Mainframe. Our Mainframe new sales grew in the low single digits year-over-year. Their performance was driven by an increased demand for Mainframe Solutions that leveraged the existing data and logic residing on the Mainframe to develop mobile and web-based applications. Additionally, we are enhancing our current application development portfolio to address larger Mainframe-to-mobile development market, which is providing us the opportunity to expand our footprint within our installed base. In the fourth quarter, we expect the renewable portfolio to be up in the 20% range year-over-year and total new sales to increase at least in the mid single digits year-over-year. I am confident we're on our way to achieving our medium-term goals.
Across every industry, business models are being transformed by software, specifically by interconnected applications. As software applications become the vital component of a global economic supply chain, and the expectations of applications speed to market accelerate, brand loyalty can be attained or lost within seconds. This makes the quality of software development more critical today than ever.
Our solutions enable enterprises to unlock the opportunities of this Application Economy, where the software is the competitive differentiator in application development is the engine of innovation. We are one of the few software providers that can deliver an integrated set of solutions, at scale across multiple platforms to help plan, develop, manage and secure applications. Let me provide you with more insight into the progress we're making towards our strategy to deliver differentiated solutions, improve sales execution and increase our velocity.
First, developing differentiated solutions in our 3 product pillars of management cloud, DevOps and security is the foundation of our strategy. In order to be a leader in the next generation of software, innovation must be the lifeblood of our company. Over the last 2 years, we have dramatically improved the efficiency of our development organization. This has allowed us to redeploy resources to focus areas such as improving the user experience and the time to value of our existing solutions, as well as bringing new products to market. An example that touches upon each of these focus areas is within our DevOps. Following the successful release of CA APM 9.7, this quarter, we launched our mobile application analytics solution. This solution provides analytics into the user experience of mobile apps and integrates with our flagship CA APM product to provide end-to-end transaction monitoring. We are already seeing early traction with the product, as demonstrated by a win at a large U.S.-based telco that will leverage CA mobile app analytics and CA APM to monitor transactions from tablets in its local stores all the way back to its data center.
Over the last 2 years, through the hard work of the APM team, our APM business has regained momentum in the market. This is evidenced by our year-to-date double-digit year-over-year growth in APM new sales and APM revenue growth returning to industry rates. 
Our security group is one of the businesses driving differentiated product development. The frequency and severity of breaches we have all seen over the course of 2014 are threatening the enterprises like never before. The marketplace is looking to software firms like CA to provide new approaches to protect their users and data. We are making investments on multiple fronts to ensure organizations can protect themselves against attacks initiated to compromise identities. One example of this is an investment in our latest release of CA advanced authentication. Malicious hackers often use stolen or compromised identities to gain access to applications. Our latest release of CA advanced authentication uses real-time analytics such as location and IP addresses to assess whether a user is who they claim to be. Simultaneously, it ensures that the password that the legitimate employee and customers use to gain access to corporate systems are all was secure and unusable if compromised.
As we stated last quarter, we are also reallocating incremental investments towards API management. APIs are the next-generation middleware of how customers are connecting hybrid cloud applications and infrastructure. We are the only vendor that can provide API management solution at the scale and security levels needed for the massive amount of data traversing these newly-created digital platforms. As an example, a large consumer electronics provider chose our API management solution for its newly architected e-commerce platform following a failure on Cyber Monday of its previous e-commerce platform. We have the ability to triple our revenue run rate with this customer over the next 12 months with our API management solutions. We see many other API management opportunities like this emerging in the marketplace. 
In addition, to the development of our core product areas, we are also redeploying our investment in 2 adjacent capacities. First, we are improving the integration with our current product set and with third-party providers. For example, we are tightening the integration between our Application Performance Management and Infrastructure Management solutions. As software becomes that underlie supply-chain of every organization, any failure in that delivery can no longer be examined independently for each specific computing layer. Instead, the service quality must be scrutinized in the context of the entire end-to-end transaction, from the mobile interface through the application server and back to the database on the Mainframe or in the cloud. Once again, we are one of few software providers that can provide that level of end-to-end visibility and scale.
Secondly, this part of the reallocation of our software development efforts, we are focusing on what customers will need in the future. We see 3 disruptive forces emerging in the market that will impact software development and we are focused on providing solutions in these areas. The first disruptive force is the unwired enterprise. How will customers manage the complexity of the billions of IP-connected devices with multiple operating systems on multiple standards which will proliferate their IP infrastructure. We have a deep history in managing network-connected devices and its natural extension of our capabilities to solve this emerging challenge.
This leads us to the second emerging market. As these IP-connected devices create a massive amount of ambient data, both structured and unstructured coming from new sources such as sensors and social networks, enterprise is under tremendous pressure to security combine their sensitive data with less risky social data and arrive at a revenue generating business outcome. Given our expertise in managing data across multiple platforms, we are working on solutions to help manage the movement of and access to this data and transform it into usable information that delivers competitive advantage to our customers.
For the third emerging opportunity, API-assembled applications, we already have a strong presence in core API management. We are leveraging our leadership in API management to help customers create and deploy interconnected applications to unlock the potential of their APIs and create new revenue opportunities.
In these 3 emerging markets, we are not making investments haphazardly or with a win at all cost mentality. We are taking a systematic approach where when we fail, we will fail early and when we win, we will have a plan in place to accelerate that product's escape velocity.
Turning now to our second major component of our strategy, I will walk you through how we are improving marketing and sales execution. We continue to improve our brand recognition in the marketplace. At CA World, our global user conference held in November, we showcased our expanding portfolio of solutions to thousands of customers and partners. Overall feedback from customers, prospects and analysts noted the emergence of a new CA with a clear focus on the challenges and opportunities faced by enterprises in a world increasingly driven by software.
Turning to sales execution. We are continuing to see evidence that our strategy of separating platinum accounts from our named and growth accounts, as well as having sales specialized by product discipline, is paying off. As I stated earlier, while new sales in the quarter declined on a year-over-year basis, this was mainly due to a tough year-over-year compare in our renewable portfolio. We are seeing 3 healthy trends in our sales execution which reinforce my confidence in the ability to grow new sales over the medium term. First, with our platinum accounts. Our third quarter renewal rates and attach rates were in line with historical trends. Additionally, we are seeing success with platinum reps truly partnering with our customers to understand their IP challenges. For example, our EMEA platinum team had a Service Virtualization win with a large multi national bank that is in the midst of a digital transformation. Longer term, this customer expects only 5% of banking interactions to occur in a physical location, thus making software development crucial to their success. The CA account team is in constant dialogue with the customer to understand how CA can help it along its digital transformation journey. This transaction marks their 6 new transaction with CA over the last 24 months, and they have increased their spending with CA over the last 4 years.
The second observation is, while our named and growth team's new sales performance was below plan, the volume of their transactions in our growth products grew year-over-year. As we increase the number of transactions, we are seeing a shortening of our sales cycles, as the technical aspect of the buying process is already proven. As a result, the quality of that pipeline has improved.
Let me provide a couple of examples. First, our Service Virtualization solution landed a win with a Fortune 500 multinational restaurant chain that had not bought a new product from CA in over 7 years. The initial transaction was just $250,000 and is focused on the specific development project. This solution alone has the ability to expand into many additional transactions over the next 24 months. Furthermore, this customer could have a greater than $5 million revenue run rate with us through cross-sell opportunities. We have identified many other accounts that have this potential.
And the second example, we forged a partnership with a leading software virtualization vendor to help build their internal DevOps strategy. They are leveraging our Service Virtualization solution to improve the speed at which they can develop and test against third-party SaaS applications, as well as their own internal IT services. Again, this is an initial transaction for which there is an opportunity to significantly expand our wallet share over the next year.
The final sales highlight I'll touch upon is with respect to the renewal portfolio. In the fourth quarter, our renewable portfolio is expected to increase in the 20% range year-over-year. As such, we are expecting at least mid-single-digit year-over-year total new sales growth, taking into account the tailwind from the sales opportunities related to renewals, plus the quality of the pipelines from our named account team.
Let me now speak to velocity. In order for us to be a modern software company, we need to deliver innovation to our customers rapidly, seamlessly and predictively. This requires a culture of empowerment where our professionals have the autonomy to drive their work forward and are held accountable for progress and results. How we get things done is as important as what that work is, and we are highly focused on evolving our internal culture so we can operate at or above market velocity. On balance, in the third quarter, we make progress against achieving our medium-term goals. We are building CA with a focus on innovation, execution and speed to compete and win in one of the fastest and most exciting industries in the world. However, we are doing so with financial discipline to preserve and enhance shareholder value over the long term.
With that, I'll turn the call over to Rich to review our third quarter financials and full-year guidance. Thank you.

headline: CA Technologies, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Mike. Before we get started with the quarter review, let me remind you that all comparisons are year-over-year and in constant currency unless otherwise indicated. This afternoon, I'm going to focus my comments on the key business drivers and p
componenttext:
Thank you, Mike. Before we get started with the quarter review, let me remind you that all comparisons are year-over-year and in constant currency unless otherwise indicated. This afternoon, I'm going to focus my comments on the key business drivers and performance indicators for the quarter. The balance of our financial details can be found in our supplemental and press release. 
As many of you are aware, the dollar continues to strengthen against most major currencies, which negatively impacts both our results and guidance. Our Q3 revenue was $1.09 billion and was down 1%; Mainframe was down 1%; Enterprise Solutions was flat; and Services declined 2%.
On an as-reported basis, Q3 renewals were down in the high 30% range but in line with our expectations. As Mike stated earlier, in Q3 fiscal 2014, we renewed our 4-year system integrator transaction for over $300 million, which created a tough year-over-year compare for both renewals and new sales this quarter. As we have previously stated, the increase and decrease year-over-year in our renewal bookings can vary on a quarterly basis due to the timing of large transactions.
Q3 total new product and capacity sales were down low teens as reported. This is due mainly to the headwinds from the renewal portfolio. The renewal yield during the quarter was approximately 90%. We continue to expect fiscal 2015 renewals to be down high single-digit year-over-year as compared to fiscal 2014 and flat year-over-year excluding the large system integrator renewal that closed in Q3 of fiscal 2014. We expect Q4 renewals to be up in the 20% range year-over-year both in constant currency and as reported.
From a geographic basis during the quarter, we saw continued improvement from our EMEA team sales execution as they grew year-over-year this quarter. This marks the EMEA team's third quarter in a row of performance that was in line with our expectations. We are also seeing good performance in our Asia team. However, North America fell short of our expectations mainly due to smaller transaction sizes. Latin America performance was again below expectations, which we believe is mainly a result of macro related headwinds.
In our Mainframe segment. Mainframe new sales including the product and capacity were up low single digit in constant currency, but down slightly as reported. Mainframe new sales benefited from good capacity sales and growth in new Mainframe products. Overall, we expect our Mainframe revenue growth to be flat to down low single digits over the medium term, which we believe is in line with the Mainframe market.
Enterprise Solutions' new product sales were down midteens in constant currency and down high teens as reported. As Mike stated, the decline in Enterprise Solutions' new product sales is mainly a result of headwinds from the renewal portfolio and smaller transaction sizes.
Services' revenue during the quarter decreased 2%. As we previously stated, the primary driver of the decline is due to us deemphasizing non-core government services subcontracting engagement that are not directly related to our software sales. We are refocusing on Services engagements that drive new product sales. As we outlined over the last 2 quarters, we currently expect professional Services revenue to decrease more than the total revenue during fiscal 2015 compared to fiscal 2014.
Current revenue backlog was down 2%. As I said before, consistent year-over-year growth in current revenue backlog is one of the indicators of future revenue growth. Current revenue backlog will likely grow when we demonstrate multiple quarters of new sales growth, while maintaining a low-90s renewal rate.
Q3 non-GAAP operating margin is 38% and GAAP operating margin was 29%. Our segment operating margins were 58% for Mainframe Solutions, 14% for Enterprise Solutions and 6% for Services.
Our Q3 non-GAAP tax rate was 26% and our GAAP tax rate was 29%. Q3 non-GAAP diluted earnings per share was $0.67, down 16% year-over-year. The decrease in our non-GAAP EPS is mainly driven by a lower non-GAAP tax rate in fiscal 2014. GAAP diluted earnings per share was $0.49, flat year-over-year.
Our Q3 CFFO was $313 million. Single-installment payments were $88 million and down year-over-year. We ended Q3 with approximately $1.29 billion in net cash. During the third quarter, we repurchased $75 million of shares, paid $111 million in dividends and repaid $502 million in debt. Additionally, we have entered into an agreement to repurchase an additional $75 million in CA shares during Q4. Including the $75 million Q4 repurchase agreement, we will have repurchased $200 million shares in fiscal 2015. We will have $800 million remaining of our original $1 billion share repurchase program at March 31, 2015.
Turning to guidance. Updated guidance is based upon exchange rates on the last day of the preceding quarter which was December 31, 2014. This includes a partial hedge of operating income.
We expect currency to have a negative impact on our full-year revenue approximately 2% and a negative impact on our fourth quarter revenue growth of approximately 4% at December 31 rates. Total revenue is still expected to be in the range of negative 2% to negative 1% in constant currency. This translates to reported revenue of $4.26 billion to $4.3 billion.
Non-GAAP diluted earnings per share growth is expected to be in the range of minus 17% to minus 14% in constant currency, an increase from our prior guidance of minus 20% to minus 18%, mainly due to the impact from lower tax rate. This reflects an approximate 18% headwind from taxes based upon a 28% tax rate. This translates to reported non-GAAP diluted earnings per share of $2.45 to $2.52.
GAAP diluted earnings per share growth is expected to be in the range of minus 7% to minus 4% in constant currency, an increase from our prior guidance of minus 12% to minus 8%. This translates to reported GAAP diluted earnings per share of $1.76 to $1.83.
Cash flow from operations are still expected to increase 5% to 12% in constant currency. This translates to reported cash flow from operations of $1 billion to $1.07 billion. The guidance does not include the effect of any future material acquisitions.
Underlying this guidance, we expect our non-GAAP tax rate to be 28%, which is down from our previous expectation of 30%. We still expect a full year GAAP operating margin of 27% and a full year non-GAAP operating margin of 37%. At the end of the year, we expect approximately 436 million shares outstanding and a weighted average diluted share count of approximately 440 million shares.
For modeling purposes, we would like to provide you with our initial expectation for fiscal year 2016. We expect our 2016 renewal portfolio to increase compared to the fiscal 2015. Given our modest expectation for Enterprise Solutions and a revenue growth headwind for Mainframe Solutions, we do not expect fiscal 2016 revenue to grow in constant currency. We expect a similar operating margin in fiscal 2016 as in 2015.
And now I will turn the call back over to Jonathan, and we will take your questions.

headline: CA Technologies, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from Raimo Lenschow of Barclays.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from Raimo Lenschow of Barclays.

headline: CA Technologies, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: I had 2 quick questions. First one for Mike. Mike, what -- if you look at the 2016 guidance, the first initial thoughts about that, it doesn't look like growth returns. What makes you confident that you are on your way to achieving your medium-term goals
componenttext: I had 2 quick questions. First one for Mike. Mike, what -- if you look at the 2016 guidance, the first initial thoughts about that, it doesn't look like growth returns. What makes you confident that you are on your way to achieving your medium-term goals to average return to growth?

headline: CA Technologies, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure, great question. I'll try to be concise as I possibly can because there's lots of things that go into that. But if I was to focus on just 3 things, first, I'd go to products. If you're going to be a software company, you have to have great innovative
componenttext: Sure, great question. I'll try to be concise as I possibly can because there's lots of things that go into that. But if I was to focus on just 3 things, first, I'd go to products. If you're going to be a software company, you have to have great innovative products. And if you look at what we've done over the last 2 years and the trajectory that we're on, we're putting some great products out into the market. A great example of that is APM. APM 2 years ago, we lost share. This is last quarter. We're up over 20%, and this is a great effort by our team that really put a lot of innovation to that product both on user interface, the capability and the lowering the cost of sales. And that's been an inspiration for all the engineers in CA. API management, the world is definitely moving to an API-enabled world. We'd really think that this is going to be a software-enabled economy. This is the glue that puts all of these disparate applications together. That product is selling extraordinarily well. Where I'll put us in the top quartile of all competitors in that space. DevOps, a lot of innovation going into DevOps. I would argue that we are the market leader in that space, really driving what we could do with virtualization in a DevOps environment. We just launched another net new product and mobile app analytics. I think we're the only company that can go directly from a mobile application, all the way through all of the middleware, into the Mainframe or the cloud. And we've got a very, very strong Mainframe group. This group has done a tremendous amount of work over the last 2 years. They've put new innovation, I think, once again, we're one of the only companies still investing in the Mainframe. The quality of our Mainframe applications has gone up tremendously. Last quarter, we did -- all of our releases had 0 defects, which I think was the first time in our history, and really makes a statement to the quality we put in place in the last couple of years. On the sales, we're in Q4, and as we're thinking about Q4 and going into 2016, I think it's the first time ever there's no structural changes going on in the sales organization. I think the restructuring that we did last year is absolutely working, and we're only going to be adding fuel to that already existing structure, not changing reporting structures and what people are working on our accounts that they're covering in a material way. And the way I look at this is it's showing up in the numbers. Now, 2 years ago, the Enterprise segment was shrinking by 20%. After one year of being here, we cut that in half. And if you take a look at where we'll end this year, Enterprise segment will be down to flat, which puts us in a position with net new products coming out in the June time frame that we'll be able to get this flywheel to move. And at the end of the day, it really comes down to the team. We put a team in place here that is really driving innovation, execution and speed. They put CA first. They're very, very competitive and they're doing it the right way, which means doing the right thing. So we're not -- put all that stuff together, it gives me confidence that we're definitely on the right path. And when I look at the numbers and the trajectory of the things that our -- paying important to, our innovative new products, is ESTG growing, is the Mainframe a stable component of our ecosystem, it gives me confidence that we're on the right track. A long answer, but thank you for a great question.

headline: CA Technologies, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2015

But it still requires to make the full year numbers a nice uplift in Q4. Can you talk a little bit about the drivers and your confidence level?

headline: CA Technologies, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2015

componenttext: Sure. So we feel we're very much on track for our guidance of 5% to 12% in constant currency. I want to remind you from my prepared remarks, we have a larger installs collections. It was $251 million in Q3 last year and it's only $88 million. So single installments were really the single biggest driver of $162 million. And the last part, I just want to remind people that we are still kind of paying off the remainder of our restructuring rebalancing payment which ends at the end of this year.

headline: CA Technologies, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Right, so the way to -- yes, it's a good question. So the way to think about it, if you look at our segment, you will see that our ES segment is slowly building and this is the first quarter in a while where we actually got to 0. You'll actually see as we
componenttext: Right, so the way to -- yes, it's a good question. So the way to think about it, if you look at our segment, you will see that our ES segment is slowly building and this is the first quarter in a while where we actually got to 0. You'll actually see as we progress through the rest of the year in order to make full year guidance, you can imagine that actually gets positive. But as we go through, we still have the Mainframe business which you see this quarter came back to minus 1. We think that as we said earlier, that still going to be minus 1, minus 2, maybe flat over time. So we need that mix to overtake the Mainframe decline in order for us to, on a consistent basis, we're going to be in positive revenue growth. And remember, in May, we'll be giving you guys full guidance. What we're trying to do is to get people to understand the headlights that they see as of right now. Clearly, the mix of how we do that business [indiscernible] will impact the amount that gets reported in Q4 versus fiscal year '16.

headline: CA Technologies, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: I guess just kind of a follow-up question on similar topics here. On the North America side, it sounds like -- I mean the macro seems relatively strong in North America and then you saw some changes to the the sales trends there with smaller deal sizes. C
componenttext: I guess just kind of a follow-up question on similar topics here. On the North America side, it sounds like -- I mean the macro seems relatively strong in North America and then you saw some changes to the the sales trends there with smaller deal sizes. Can you talk about whether that's something that you caught on your and anything around sales execution, is there something happening in the market that's impacting that? And what are the prospects of that improving as we move into Q4 and into 2016?

headline: CA Technologies, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Hey, Walter, it's Mike. I'm encouraged by the number that we're getting and it kind of goes to John DiFucci's comment where people are looking at CA a little bit differently, which means we're getting into more sales cycle. As we're getting into these sal
componenttext: Hey, Walter, it's Mike. I'm encouraged by the number that we're getting and it kind of goes to John DiFucci's comment where people are looking at CA a little bit differently, which means we're getting into more sales cycle. As we're getting into these sales cycle, I don't think it's different for anybody. The technical buyer wants to try and buy. And we have an opportunity to do what we do a mezzanine transaction, get it in, make sure it works, they usually do that now before they go for the big transaction. I think you have to be very careful to be an LS 100 [ph] these days. That's how you get really awkward and jump the bookings quarter-to-quarter. What we've been training our sales force to do is get in there, we'll very confident in our products, we're more than happy to do try and buy, we're more than happy to do a proof of concept. And in the end, we take a look at over a 12 to 18-month time frame, we think it's going to shorten sales cycles rather than a long elongate them. Having a very long sales cycle for a very large transaction compared to having 8 to 10 transactions going on at the same time, where the customer sees the true value for product, we just think that's the way the industry is moving and you're seeing some of that transition happen. It's been happening all year long. So I don't see anything systemic. I like the North American market. I think we feel very good about security. That portfolio is very competitive, and we see a lot of need for security. I love what we're doing in DevOps because I think as customers start building applications, especially custom applications for mobile, I think we're very well positioned for that. And then when you take a look at our management cloud, everybody wants to understand where these transactions are. Is it the network that's down? Is that the application that down? Is it the hardware that's down? We're one of the few companies that can monitor that scale across multiplatform. So I feel pretty good about those problems being solved in North America. Europe was very strong. Once again, 3 quarters in a row Europe's been very strong. We definitely over performed in Asia this quarter, so it's a very happy with that. The big area that we are a little bit surprised about is how poorly Latin America did for this last quarter, and we're taking a look at that from an economic perspective as well as from an execution perspective.

headline: CA Technologies, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: And then, Mike, something you talked about the past is an attach product sales, sales that are happening outside the renewal and understanding that's still a smaller portion of your new business. But what can you tell us about what you saw in that type of
componenttext: And then, Mike, something you talked about the past is an attach product sales, sales that are happening outside the renewal and understanding that's still a smaller portion of your new business. But what can you tell us about what you saw in that type of business in the third quarter in the pipeline for the fourth quarter?

headline: CA Technologies, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: So this is Rich. So what we really saw -- Mike just touched on it. If you see the growth accounts, we saw higher volume than previous year, but the actual transaction size was smaller. And those are all coming out of the renewal cycle. If you look at our
componenttext: So this is Rich. So what we really saw -- Mike just touched on it. If you see the growth accounts, we saw higher volume than previous year, but the actual transaction size was smaller. And those are all coming out of the renewal cycle. If you look at our plant in them accounts, those will have a much higher attach rate and are much tighter to the renewal date. And so in North America, we have the contracts for the platinum but we saw in Service Virtualization as an example, it was a smaller deal size but more volume, and that's where the demand and expand motto that we're asking those guys to perform.

headline: CA Technologies, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Daniel Ives of FBR Capital Markets.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Daniel Ives of FBR Capital Markets.

headline: CA Technologies, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: So I'm waiting for a five-point question from this. So as you guys gone through our pickups and sales, what do you think the biggest challenge and opportunity is on the other end for the next year as we look out?
componenttext: So I'm waiting for a five-point question from this. So as you guys gone through our pickups and sales, what do you think the biggest challenge and opportunity is on the other end for the next year as we look out?

headline: CA Technologies, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think the biggest challenge is driving towards this notion that customers want to try and buy before they do large transactions. As an enterprise software company, that's a bit of a change in skill set. We've been working on that over the last couple of
componenttext: I think the biggest challenge is driving towards this notion that customers want to try and buy before they do large transactions. As an enterprise software company, that's a bit of a change in skill set. We've been working on that over the last couple of years. But if you look at the way all of our marketing programs run, all of our lead generation programs run, our sales sensation works, how we're allocating resources, it's really driving to getting the software in the hands of the people that are going to use it so they can see the value and then come in for to the larger purchase. So I think that, that's a systemic challenge that all software companies have to deal with. I think we recognized this 2 years ago and started working our way towards it. But I wouldn't the clear victory on it as of yet. Secondly, as it comes down to net new product innovation. This market is changing so quickly, customers are so demanding that you have to have your innovation thinking cap on. You have to imagine the problems that customers are going to have 1 to 2 years out, because it takes enterprise company to build software at scale at least a year to get it through the development process through the testing process to make sure that it works as promised and at scale. And so that's something that we're constantly, constantly thinking about. And I think we're in a much, much better shape to accomplish that mission today than we were a year ago.

headline: CA Technologies, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Matt Hedberg of RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Matt Hedberg of RBC Capital Markets.

headline: CA Technologies, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Mike, you called on your prepared remarks security, obviously remains in the headlines almost daily. Your Identity nexus management products, should we see a benefit. I'm curious how customers look at physically security solutions from CA versus more pure
componenttext: Mike, you called on your prepared remarks security, obviously remains in the headlines almost daily. Your Identity nexus management products, should we see a benefit. I'm curious how customers look at physically security solutions from CA versus more pure plays. And are you seeing a higher attach rate from these security solutions?

headline: CA Technologies, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think we -- first of all, we're considered to be a very top-tier vendor, but the differentiator for us is scale and multiplatform. When you think of all the security problems that are happening, especially in Identity and Access Management, you do not w
componenttext: I think we -- first of all, we're considered to be a very top-tier vendor, but the differentiator for us is scale and multiplatform. When you think of all the security problems that are happening, especially in Identity and Access Management, you do not want to have security happen in just one geographic location or with just one application. And as companies are starting to have API-enabled applications, which is one application talking to another, they need something absolutely super secure to make sure that, that -- not only that, that person is who they say they are, that machine is who they say they are. And I put us in the upper quadrant of any company that can handle that with sophistication and scale, and that's the area where we're really, really driving home the differentiation of CA.

headline: CA Technologies, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: And then, Rich, Enterprise margin I believe they're 14% in the quarter. Can you remind us again on where those are going to go longer term? And then second, should we expect the sequential decline there in the fourth quarter similar to the last few years?
componenttext: And then, Rich, Enterprise margin I believe they're 14% in the quarter. Can you remind us again on where those are going to go longer term? And then second, should we expect the sequential decline there in the fourth quarter similar to the last few years?

headline: CA Technologies, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Right, so that's a good question. If you look through the first 3 quarters of last year, you'll see that we are running ahead of where we said we would come in. And so you can see, this year has a similar pattern to it, so we're very comfortable with that
componenttext: Right, so that's a good question. If you look through the first 3 quarters of last year, you'll see that we are running ahead of where we said we would come in. And so you can see, this year has a similar pattern to it, so we're very comfortable with that 37% margin that were talked about earlier on guidance. If you think about the ES segment, you can see that building over time. But yes, there's a lot of things that will be allocated back to the ES segment. An example could be new sales and marketing, things of that nature, procurement. And so you'll see a dip in the fourth quarter, as we move out over time, what we told you before is we expect that to grow into the teens.

headline: CA Technologies, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Matt Williams of Evercore.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Matt Williams of Evercore.

headline: CA Technologies, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Obviously calling in for Kirk. Just 2 from us. I guess, number one, in terms of the smaller deal sizes in Enterprise, especially North America, was there any particular product segment that this trend sort of impacted or was it kind of across the board fr
componenttext: Obviously calling in for Kirk. Just 2 from us. I guess, number one, in terms of the smaller deal sizes in Enterprise, especially North America, was there any particular product segment that this trend sort of impacted or was it kind of across the board from a product portfolio standpoint?

headline: CA Technologies, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think it was pretty much across the board for any of the growth products. So when you're taking a look at our API management, you take a look at Service Virtualization, those types of products, those -- all of the higher growth products kind of exhibite
componenttext: I think it was pretty much across the board for any of the growth products. So when you're taking a look at our API management, you take a look at Service Virtualization, those types of products, those -- all of the higher growth products kind of exhibited that kind of feel. We also have some smaller deals happen in the midmarket in the unified Infrastructure Management, which is exactly what we've been pushing for. We use to only sell that product in that suite of products to some of the biggest customers in the world. The fact that a couple billion dollar companies started to use that product and understand it, and that product comes from a very sophisticated try and buy platform with Unified Infrastructure Management Snap. I think that once again, these are the confidence builders that you want to see, because this is how a modern software company goes to market.

headline: CA Technologies, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: And I guess maybe as a follow-up to that, it sounds like you're see more and more of these smaller font deals with the payoff being that the customer circles back and re-up down the road. Is the pace at which customers are coming back to you to expand the
componenttext: And I guess maybe as a follow-up to that, it sounds like you're see more and more of these smaller font deals with the payoff being that the customer circles back and re-up down the road. Is the pace at which customers are coming back to you to expand their initial deployment, is that accelerating at all relative to what you saw 6 or 12 months ago?

headline: CA Technologies, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think the data is too jump you right now. I don't think our pattern recognition is great. I think you'll see in Q2 for example accelerated faster than I thought it would be. And in Q3, it didn't accelerate as far as I thought it would be. So it will tak
componenttext: I think the data is too jump you right now. I don't think our pattern recognition is great. I think you'll see in Q2 for example accelerated faster than I thought it would be. And in Q3, it didn't accelerate as far as I thought it would be. So it will take other bit of time to get the pattern recognition and the body of transactions where we have a feel for how this works quarter in and quarter out.

headline: CA Technologies, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Phil Winslow of Crédit Suisse.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Phil Winslow of Crédit Suisse.

headline: CA Technologies, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: I just have a question on the Mainframe side. I wondered if you can comment on the pricing environment that you seen there and maybe compare it to the past couple quarters, past couple years. And also, just as you lower than the Mainframe side, it just so
componenttext: I just have a question on the Mainframe side. I wondered if you can comment on the pricing environment that you seen there and maybe compare it to the past couple quarters, past couple years. And also, just as you lower than the Mainframe side, it just sort of how you're thinking about that segment especially with a new Z launch out of IBM? Curious for any color there, that'd be great.

headline: CA Technologies, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: I have 2 things and I'm going to get Rich to weigh on it as well. From a pricing perspective, we see a lot of stability, and there is a differentiation. I think customers are getting very careful about Mainframe purchases especially maintenance. If you ca
componenttext: I have 2 things and I'm going to get Rich to weigh on it as well. From a pricing perspective, we see a lot of stability, and there is a differentiation. I think customers are getting very careful about Mainframe purchases especially maintenance. If you can't show in a maintenance cycle that you've actually put some sweat equity into adding value to existing code, I think you're getting a tremendous amount of pushback from customers. So that's why in my opening remarks I talked about the Mainframe and I haven't let them off the hook in any way, shape or form on innovation. And every new release has got to have something in there that is better than the previous release, whether it be user interface, the amount of mips it uses, whether it's ease in use of that application adjustment new SKUs, coupled with features that have been on the box for a while with respect to customers. So I think if you do that, we've seen a lot of stability in our maintenance pricing, and I think our customer satisfaction just last quarter was the highest in the history of CA. So I like the imagery of that. I like the feel of that business. Now I do think we have some more opportunity with what's going on with the announcement of the Z System coming from IBM. IBM, we participate in the relationship with them in 3 ways. They are a great partner for us in the systems integrators side. They are a great partner for us with respect to the hardware side. They share a lot of data with us with what we're doing in the product road map. They want that platform to be as powerful as possible, and they encourage companies like CA to write software for that platform. And then, of course, we do build out on the software side. So when I took a look at the whole relationship and we take a look at their investment am I think we spent $1 billion over the last 5 years. I think that's net good for us because at the end of the day, customers are going to want to have choice. There are certain customer segments that we like dealing with CA, and they could picked any vendor they wanted on the Mainframe. They standardized on us and they want us to invest. And I think that, that's -- the fact that IBM has made that platform once again relevant, I think him as a good showing for us in our Mainframe segment. Now Rich spent a lot of time on pricing and a lot of the maintenance contract, maybe he can give some contextual information, Rich?

headline: CA Technologies, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: So I would say we had a strong new Mainframe sales with low single digit growth, and that's important because as we talked about earlier, we had a lighter, new renewable portfolio. So they had single digit growth on a lighter renewal portfolio is a pretty
componenttext: So I would say we had a strong new Mainframe sales with low single digit growth, and that's important because as we talked about earlier, we had a lighter, new renewable portfolio. So they had single digit growth on a lighter renewal portfolio is a pretty strong statement of the platform, and then that also say we saw good attach rate, and as we have 90-plus percent like normal on the renewal yield, so that means we not trading our mainstream for the incremental sales. As far as the Z box, I think it will benefit is over time. It helps our entire ecosystem, as Mike said with a total cost of computing driving that down. The fact that Z Linux will play a bigger and bigger part of that, we have a lot of products on the distributed side that, that is a bit and we're really the only vendor with IBM that have a strong Linux and strong Mainframe. And if you read a lot of their prepared remarks, that is becoming a bigger and bigger place for people to consolidate their Linux forums back onto the Mainframe and that plays right into our sweet spot.

headline: CA Technologies, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Michael Turits with Raymond James.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Michael Turits with Raymond James.

headline: CA Technologies, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Back to the revenue guide for next year. The street was at flat on a nominal basis. Obviously, we have some currency headwinds. So do you think that this check meet -- can we just get ahead of ourselves on that, or is there anything that actually diminish
componenttext: Back to the revenue guide for next year. The street was at flat on a nominal basis. Obviously, we have some currency headwinds. So do you think that this check meet -- can we just get ahead of ourselves on that, or is there anything that actually diminished in terms of the outlook for when you start to inflect that towards growth?

headline: CA Technologies, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: So as we talked about all the time, Michael, the revenue backlog, especially the constant line is really the best indicator for our next year, and we currently sit at a minus 2 in constant currency, we think at this point in time, it's prudent to tell you
componenttext: So as we talked about all the time, Michael, the revenue backlog, especially the constant line is really the best indicator for our next year, and we currently sit at a minus 2 in constant currency, we think at this point in time, it's prudent to tell you that were closer to the flatter end of that to start to see good growth. As I think John has asked the question earlier, Q4 is always an important in the quarter for us. How that booking is recorded either ratable over time or a little more upfront will start to push that. And again, were talking about the difference here is maybe $30 million as to which direction you're going to really land. So we are trying to indicate for people was just headlights. We'll come out with the proper guidance next May. But we don't want to have people too far ahead. Because as you can see, in order for us to get on track with our guidance, you'll see a fairly strong Q4 from that revenue standpoint. We want to make sure people understood over time, you will still to make sure that you're looking at that revenue backlog.

headline: CA Technologies, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Abhey Lamba of Mizuho Securities.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Abhey Lamba of Mizuho Securities.

headline: CA Technologies, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to dig into that a little bit more. You're calling for your revenue performance to be in line with market, but there is clearly disruption at some of the smaller players in the space. So is there any opportunity for you take gain shares with
componenttext: I just wanted to dig into that a little bit more. You're calling for your revenue performance to be in line with market, but there is clearly disruption at some of the smaller players in the space. So is there any opportunity for you take gain shares within them? Are there any structure headwinds in the market that you're seeing, Rich, that could -- would negate that and get you back to the market growth rate? So is there opportunity for you to do better than that?

headline: CA Technologies, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: It's always difficult to get somebody to switch platforms of any size. If you're a small player and you're moving off the Mainframe, we're not trying to keep you on the Mainframe. We try to get you into the distributed products. Have you made that archite
componenttext: It's always difficult to get somebody to switch platforms of any size. If you're a small player and you're moving off the Mainframe, we're not trying to keep you on the Mainframe. We try to get you into the distributed products. Have you made that architectural decision if that's where we want to go. If you're a large Mainframe user, we're trying to get you to use as many of our products, whether it be on the enterprise side or on the Mainframe side, but we don't go out and target at this point in time competitive replacements of large-scale Mainframe applications and the cost of sale is just super prohibitive. It's more important for us to leverage that Mainframe relationship to increase the capacity usage, add net new product and really drive into the distributed side of the house, the ESTG side of the house, and that work out really well, especially the larger Mainframe clients. I can't think of any of our top 100 customers that have a -- that we have a Mainframe relationship with that we don't have a significant distributed relationship with.

headline: CA Technologies, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Can I just add one thing to that. I think when you look at our level of investment outpaces a lot of the smaller vendors. So as they come up with a newer box, what you really start this is our ability to exploit that over the next year or so. And that doe
componenttext: Can I just add one thing to that. I think when you look at our level of investment outpaces a lot of the smaller vendors. So as they come up with a newer box, what you really start this is our ability to exploit that over the next year or so. And that does make people decide whether they want to switch to any single product companies over to us. So I do think every time there's new technology, as I said earlier, that allows you to run Z and Linux, and we're one of the few guys that can do that. It gives us a leg up when they do a renewal versus our competitor's renewal.

headline: CA Technologies, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Gregg Moskowitz of Cowen & Company.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Gregg Moskowitz of Cowen & Company.

headline: CA Technologies, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: I guess the first question is despite historical issues in Europe, as you noted earlier, your sales execution grew year-over-year and it's the third consecutive quarter of in line performance. Do you think, Mike, do you think you've turned a corner in Eur
componenttext: I guess the first question is despite historical issues in Europe, as you noted earlier, your sales execution grew year-over-year and it's the third consecutive quarter of in line performance. Do you think, Mike, do you think you've turned a corner in Europe?

headline: CA Technologies, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think we always use the word Europe as one amorphous, homogeneous idea. Europe is not one thing. I think you have to take a look at Europe and this piece parts. I like what's happening in the U.K. and I absolutely think we turned the corner there. I rea
componenttext: I think we always use the word Europe as one amorphous, homogeneous idea. Europe is not one thing. I think you have to take a look at Europe and this piece parts. I like what's happening in the U.K. and I absolutely think we turned the corner there. I really like what is going on in parts of central Europe that we had a very good showing in France this quarter. I think that there's some interesting things going on, on there. Germany is an area where we need to invest. I think that our ability to perform in Germany needs to be shored up. I think that that's a very large market and we are definitely not even getting close to our fair share in that market. And when you think a look at Spain, Portugal, those areas, they're tougher markets not just for us but for all of us. So when I think about Europe in totality, I think we're executing better in each and every market, but some markets are just better than others. I'm very encouraged once again by the U.K. I want to do more in Germany. I think that, that needs to be part of our strategy in 2016, and we are definitely one of the top players in the Nordics but it's also a relatively small market.

headline: CA Technologies, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2015

componenttext: Our final question comes from Mark Moerdler of Bernstein.

headline: CA Technologies, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: So as we stated earlier, we do have an impact in the quarter. The revenue was a minus 2 -- and it's going to be 4% in Q4. So full year down a little bit 1.5 points. So it definitely have that draw downward. From an EPS, it was minus $0.02 in the Q3, but i
componenttext: So as we stated earlier, we do have an impact in the quarter. The revenue was a minus 2 -- and it's going to be 4% in Q4. So full year down a little bit 1.5 points. So it definitely have that draw downward. From an EPS, it was minus $0.02 in the Q3, but it will be a benefit in Q4. And the reason for the benefit in Q4 is a lot of what we have already done with the treasury team, actually times out at the end of the year. So it has much less of a flattening effect on EPS for the full year.

headline: CA Technologies, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you. And at this time, I'd like to turn the call back to management for closing comments.
componenttext: Thank you. And at this time, I'd like to turn the call back to management for closing comments.

headline: CA Technologies, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, thank you very much, and thank you, everyone, for being on the call. I know everyone's super busy. I really appreciate all the questions. I think your big takeaway from this call should be that it is not lost on this management team that there is st
componenttext: Well, thank you very much, and thank you, everyone, for being on the call. I know everyone's super busy. I really appreciate all the questions. I think your big takeaway from this call should be that it is not lost on this management team that there is still a lot of work to do. But we do have a team in place that can do the work and do it in a thoughtful way. We are clearly on a journey, most journeys are not straight lines. But if you take a look at what's happened over the last 8 quarters, just about every metric we measure is moving up into the right. We are never going to be happy with the pace if that's happening at. We always want to be faster, but our focus on innovation, execution and constantly increasing the speed at which this company operates I think is going to put us to where we really want to get to, which is somewhere in the mid-single digits growth with the high 30s operating margin, and I feel pretty confident that we're well on our way to make that happen.

headline: CA Technologies, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2015
