headline: CA, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, May 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Two quick questions, if I may. First, Mike, you talked a little bit about the areas of strength and weakness. Can you talk a little bit more specifically on which products performed well during the quarter? And where did you fall somewhat short? Just to g
componenttext: Two quick questions, if I may. First, Mike, you talked a little bit about the areas of strength and weakness. Can you talk a little bit more specifically on which products performed well during the quarter? And where did you fall somewhat short? Just to give us a better understanding of like where do you have to look. And then I have one follow-up.

headline: CA, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, May 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. Thank you, Raimo. With respect to the products, it's pretty much been the same thing all year long. The growth products have continued to do well, they did very well in Q4. When you take a look at Release Automation, Service Virtualization, API mana
componenttext: Sure. Thank you, Raimo. With respect to the products, it's pretty much been the same thing all year long. The growth products have continued to do well, they did very well in Q4. When you take a look at Release Automation, Service Virtualization, API management had an extraordinary quarter in the mid-30s growth. Service Virtualization was in the high 20s. And then we had good performance by some of our more mature products with -- Security was up in the low 20s and e-commerce had the best quarter that, well, we've ever had. Over the course of the year, we've seen a lot of lumpiness in some of our value products. The big standout there is APM management -- API management. It had the -- a really, really strong quarter, grew above our plan for the year. And if you remember, this particular product was shrinking 2 years ago, and we've definitely got it into a place where we're definitely seeing growth and continue to see growth. So if I was to characterize those as the big winners, and thematically, the newer products are selling very well and a little bit of lumpiness in some of the value products.

headline: CA, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, May 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. Perfect. And then if I look about -- if I look into the guidance, and maybe a question for both of you, you now have like -- you guide for about 200 bps margin improvement. But we're also in that space where we want to see the acceleration of growth
componenttext: Okay. Perfect. And then if I look about -- if I look into the guidance, and maybe a question for both of you, you now have like -- you guide for about 200 bps margin improvement. But we're also in that space where we want to see the acceleration of growth. Can you talk a little bit about how you handle that? Especially given you were not really ready to do this before. Are we kind of coming out of the investment phase and now coming out with more growth, you can do that? Or just talk us through how we can get comfortable with that one.

headline: CA, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, May 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. I would characterize it as the last 2 years we spent really getting operationally sound. And when you take a look at our confidence in getting to 39%, it's now we're at a point where we're pretty much steady stream. I still think there's room for im
componenttext: Sure. I would characterize it as the last 2 years we spent really getting operationally sound. And when you take a look at our confidence in getting to 39%, it's now we're at a point where we're pretty much steady stream. I still think there's room for improvement down the road with respect to the Enterprise segment, but that's got to be associated with growth. So we've been focused over the last 2 years completely on organic growth. So getting to that 39% from an organic perspective, I think, is where the company is operating very, very well. Net Promoter Score's gone up. The talent that we've been able to attract to the company and the talent that we had in the company is operating at what I would consider to be pretty much best of class. When you take a look at where we spend revenue on a percentage basis -- of where we spend as a percentage of revenue in all the categories, I'm feeling much more comfortable about that. So now we've got a very good platform in which we can start layering on growth. The new products that we've been investing in and building out over the last year are coming to market. We have a number of products we'll be launching at CA World, so I feel good about that. So to get to the 39%, I think we've got a little bit more work ahead of us coming into the quarter -- coming into the next quarter or 2. But I feel pretty confident. Organically, we're in a good spot to get to that kind of operating margin.

headline: CA, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, May 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Daniel Ives of FBR Capital Markets.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Daniel Ives of FBR Capital Markets.

headline: CA, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, May 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: It's Jim actually in for Dan. Can you just give us an update around your M&A strategy and what you might be thinking there, if there's any particular areas you're interested in? Or just any updates?
componenttext: It's Jim actually in for Dan. Can you just give us an update around your M&A strategy and what you might be thinking there, if there's any particular areas you're interested in? Or just any updates?

headline: CA, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, May 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. I'd like to be very clear. We are not bidding on Microsoft. So we can put that one to bed. It seems there's a lot of conversation about that. Our strategy has not changed with respect to the product and product placement. Our #1 priority is organic.
componenttext: Sure. I'd like to be very clear. We are not bidding on Microsoft. So we can put that one to bed. It seems there's a lot of conversation about that. Our strategy has not changed with respect to the product and product placement. Our #1 priority is organic. We spend a lot of our time and effort thinking about products that we can build and improving the products we have. I've also said consistently that we will spend $300 million to $500 million a year on average. And to the extent that we see products and companies in the market that make sense to our strategy and hit our internal hurdle rates with respect to valuation, I feel very confident I've got a management team that can execute. Going back to my -- the previous answer I talked about on how we're improving the operations, I think we've cleaned up a lot of those types of issues. So we have the ability to be able to do that. And the other thing that should be very clear, I talked about it in the prepared remarks, is we made our plan on EMEA, which is the first time that we've done that in an awful long time. I think the EMEA team has done a very, very good job, getting very serious about how our products need to be represented in that market. So that's a confidence builder. And when you've got that distribution engine working in a market as big as that, you can start thinking about acquisitions again.

headline: CA, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, May 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. Great. And then maybe if you could just talk about what are the some of the biggest changes or just different dynamics you might be seeing with customers today versus a year ago, and maybe specifically toward some of the next gen and newer products?
componenttext: Okay. Great. And then maybe if you could just talk about what are the some of the biggest changes or just different dynamics you might be seeing with customers today versus a year ago, and maybe specifically toward some of the next gen and newer products?

headline: CA, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, May 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: It's one of those things where I think it's happening across the industry. Customers are being very specific about the capacity that they want. And they want to make sure that whatever they buy works in their environment. So that's why you see all of our
componenttext: It's one of those things where I think it's happening across the industry. Customers are being very specific about the capacity that they want. And they want to make sure that whatever they buy works in their environment. So that's why you see all of our investment into try and buy, even for our perpetual products. And our increase in the number of -- we've gotten much better in a number of different product areas of being able to do proof of concept. We are absolutely well tuned to a business model of try and buy, landing these mezzanine transactions and then coming back over time and selling the larger transaction. And I think that puts a lot of responsibility on us to have great products, high customer satisfaction and really, really focus on product quality, because the days of being able to sell a large enterprise license and the customer not being able to try and understand how that product works in their environment, I think those days are long gone. And we are well, well on our way to a new business model.

headline: CA, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, May 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of John DiFucci of Jefferies.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of John DiFucci of Jefferies.

headline: CA, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, May 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: First question, guys, I'm just trying to make sure if I understand if your sort of outlook has gotten a little bit worse than it was before. Because renewals are supposed to be up in the mid-teens for next year right now, which I think is a little bit bet
componenttext: First question, guys, I'm just trying to make sure if I understand if your sort of outlook has gotten a little bit worse than it was before. Because renewals are supposed to be up in the mid-teens for next year right now, which I think is a little bit better than you thought it would be and -- which makes sense because of the slippage of renewals from this quarter into next. Previously, you had said that revenue would not grow on a constant currency basis, and now you're saying it's going to decline a couple of percent on a constant currency basis. And I think about those renewals pushing from this quarter to next quarter, and it's a big delta, right? I mean, it was supposed to be up, I think, around -- I mean, we thought around 15%, 20%. Now it's down in the high-single digits. So that would hurt this year and help next year relative to this year. Not a lot. I realize the timing of the year, but a little bit anyway. And I'm just curious as to why revenue is -- the outlook is a little bit worse than -- at least on the margin. I don't know. When you said it wasn't going to grow, it could mean it could decline, but you could have said it's going to decline, too. Are you sort of just assuming, Mike, some of the stuff that happened here? Or it's just going to take longer? It wasn't just renewals and does it takes longer to fix over the course of next year?

headline: CA, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, May 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: John, I'd give you a little bit of color and then I'll give you -- let Rich walk through some specifics on the numbers. We've been at this for 2 years. And to change the trajectory of something like CA, is it 2 years, 1 month and a day? Is it 2 years, 6 m
componenttext: John, I'd give you a little bit of color and then I'll give you -- let Rich walk through some specifics on the numbers. We've been at this for 2 years. And to change the trajectory of something like CA, is it 2 years, 1 month and a day? Is it 2 years, 6 months and a day? It's taken a bit longer to get some of this product traction and getting the sales environment to sell consistently. When I look across the board, as I said, I was super happy with EMEA. They've been able to sell outside of the renewal. They've been able to sell standalone. In the U.S., we have pockets where it worked well and pockets where it didn't work so well. In order for us to get to that growth, we have to keep our fingers on several levers, and I talked about that in the prepared remarks. Number one is we have to get net new product that is in tune to what a customer wants to buy. So we need more net new products to offset some of the legacy products, and we're on that all day, every day. And secondly, we have to have more consistency in our sales operations. It's not okay to be good in certain territories and not good in other territories. This is something I'm spending an awful lot of time on with the sales leadership team, and we're going to be focused on that to get the kind of consistent result. Now there's a number of mechanics, some of which you already pointed out. I'll get Rich to talk about some of the mechanics that show up in the CA model.

headline: CA, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, May 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: John, so if you think through where we did say we were going to end up with our renewals and bookings, you can view about 2/3 of that were actually fiscal '16 renewals that would come into our fiscal year-end. They'd be in their calendar year. Those trans
componenttext: John, so if you think through where we did say we were going to end up with our renewals and bookings, you can view about 2/3 of that were actually fiscal '16 renewals that would come into our fiscal year-end. They'd be in their calendar year. Those transactions, we now -- they did not occur in the quarter. So we didn't lose any of those. They just will now happen at their normal expiration date. Most of those expiration dates are back-half loaded. So as opposed to closing a transaction in Q4 of fiscal '15, we plumb them now that the majority of those will close in Q3, Q4. With the ratable model, you can see if that pushes. So that's just a statement of about 2/3 of that booking change. But there is 1/3 of that booking change, as Mike talked about, where we didn't do as well in North America freestanding, and Services continues to be a drag. Services is a drag of about 0.5 point. So mechanically, those are the things that drove the change just in the overall bookings. On a positive note, Mike alluded to earlier it though, if you look at our new sales, about 1/3 of that now is our new fast-growing product set. So as that product set becomes a bigger and bigger part of the overall new sales, it will over time overshadow the older products that are either in decline or flat.

headline: CA, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, May 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. Guys, that's really helpful. If I could ask my second question because you guys said a few things there that I think are interesting. And sort of when I look at this quarter and I think about what you're saying, renewals were down low-single digits
componenttext: Okay. Guys, that's really helpful. If I could ask my second question because you guys said a few things there that I think are interesting. And sort of when I look at this quarter and I think about what you're saying, renewals were down low-single digits this quarter, and we understand why. And now they'll come in the back half of next year, which explains the first question. But new business was down in the high-single digits this quarter. And I -- listen, with all due respect, both of you guys are very logical people and really sharp people from my experience. And we hear of good things in the field about CA. We hear of good things from customers. We hear of good things from partners and others. But at some point, you guys have been at this, doing what makes sense for this company. But when do you -- is there a point where you say, "Geez, you know what? Maybe with this kind of software, with this product set, maybe we should just stop trying to grow and just give it -- give cash back to investors," give more -- I mean, you're already giving a lot of cash to investors, but just give more back to investors and run it a little differently. Listen, I'm not saying you should give up. I'm just wondering if that, I don't know, should be considered because we do hear about good things here. And with all due respect, we think you guys have done all the right things, but we don't see it yet.

headline: CA, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, May 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: So John, it's Rich again. We currently already give 65% of our free cash flow back to our investors, so that's a pretty healthy return. If you go back to those transactions that moved out -- and you heard Mike talk earlier about some of the other products
componenttext: So John, it's Rich again. We currently already give 65% of our free cash flow back to our investors, so that's a pretty healthy return. If you go back to those transactions that moved out -- and you heard Mike talk earlier about some of the other products. An example, a lot of the existing not new products, they grow via capacity growth, which is ELA driven. So to the degree that those ELAs naturally are going to happen in the back of the year, a lot of the growth of the traditional products will happen in the capacity. As Mike said, it's been lumpy. The first half of the year, we actually saw some good growth in some of our more traditional products. So those -- so we are not giving up on that product set at all. We do see that just happening more still in tune with the natural expiration date. I think as far as North America, North America still needs to continue to grow outside of renewals, but the platinum accounts actually did well around the world in all quarters. So they're tied to the renewal cycle, but they performed well, and we saw growth in our named accounts.

headline: CA, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, May 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: John, you're asking a very good question. And to think that we haven't played around with some of those ideas would be naïve. So the way I would also look at it is this way. If I saw consistent poor performance on a global basis, I would be more apt to t
componenttext: John, you're asking a very good question. And to think that we haven't played around with some of those ideas would be naïve. So the way I would also look at it is this way. If I saw consistent poor performance on a global basis, I would be more apt to take a look at a different strategy. But when I can see us turning Asia Pac, turning EMEA, platinum working pretty much across the globe and North America, especially in the named and growth, being spotty, where it works really, really well with some territories and some executives and it doesn't work nearly as well with some territories and some executives, it gives me confidence that if I can understand that and get more products and continue to improve customer satisfaction, Net Promoter Scores, that we'll be able to get this company to grow. The other thing, too, in the category of no good deed goes unpunished, we have become a mature disciplined company. So some of these renewals that customers wanted to do in Q4, the economics were not in our favor. And I've really pushed hard to not discount these new products. These new products are of high value. We're selling them across the globe. And just because you've had an ELA and an experience with CA where, at the end of our Q4, you want to squeeze us on economics, I'm just not willing to give up that kind of value. And I think that was a little bit of a different performance that customers have seen from CA than they have seen in the past. So hopefully, that gives you a little bit more color on the machinations that go into running CA.

headline: CA, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, May 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Ken Talanian of JPMorgan.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Ken Talanian of JPMorgan.

headline: CA, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, May 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: You mentioned earlier that you closed a substantially lower number of -- fewer quarter renewals than historically. And you just mentioned that you've done a lot of [ph] discounting. I was wondering, as part of that, how do you see the difference between t
componenttext: You mentioned earlier that you closed a substantially lower number of -- fewer quarter renewals than historically. And you just mentioned that you've done a lot of [ph] discounting. I was wondering, as part of that, how do you see the difference between trying to maximize the total value of that renewals or potentially you elongating the sales cycle related to the new products attached to that renewal?

headline: CA, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, May 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Great question. At the end of the day, you want to hold the value of your highest-performing products and make sure that the market doesn't deteriorate and commoditize them. The other thing is we have a huge event called CA World where we bring all of our
componenttext: Great question. At the end of the day, you want to hold the value of your highest-performing products and make sure that the market doesn't deteriorate and commoditize them. The other thing is we have a huge event called CA World where we bring all of our customers together. And if you start selling software like rugs at a Turkish bazaar, you are not considered to be an honest broker and you eventually get into a cycle where your product commoditizes quicker than you want it to, and then you stop investing in R&D. And then when you stop investing in R&D, you get taken over by competitors. I've seen that happen so much in our industry that I think you have to take a stand on where is value. And if you hold the line on the value and you also hold the line on the value of the ELA, these ELAs drive an incredible amount of value for our customers. And you want to be in a situation where you're negotiating fairly, but you don't want to give up the economics just to make a number for one particular quarter when you're giving up the long-term and medium-term value of your company.

headline: CA, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, May 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And sort of related to that, one of the items you mentioned earlier on the call was increasing the velocity of sales. You have mentioned it a few times in the past as well. I'm curious, how much of your portfolio could you move over to inside sales
componenttext: Okay. And sort of related to that, one of the items you mentioned earlier on the call was increasing the velocity of sales. You have mentioned it a few times in the past as well. I'm curious, how much of your portfolio could you move over to inside sales or otherwise develop into something that could see higher velocity than you have historically.

headline: CA, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, May 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: So today, we have a fair amount of inside sales that supports what we call our named accounts. So for you guys, account 501 through 2,000, and they support those teams of people that are around the world. We've added to that team last year, and we'll cont
componenttext: So today, we have a fair amount of inside sales that supports what we call our named accounts. So for you guys, account 501 through 2,000, and they support those teams of people that are around the world. We've added to that team last year, and we'll continue to add to that team again. We've seen some very good success rates for certain products, where the inside sales team was really able to percolate that and then it was actually closed by the named account rep. But we've had a lot of good touching with the customers. The other place we're using inside sales is on these smaller renewals where it wouldn't be a platinum account. It's now maybe only $0.5 million renewal, and they are touching them on a more frequent basis. And you heard Mike talk earlier about our customer sat scores going up. A lot of that is tied right to the more you interact with the customers, the more customer satisfaction we have. And we have seen a turnaround in some of those accounts that were dormant actually starting to buy either incremental capacity or new products.

headline: CA, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, May 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Michael Turits of Raymond James.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Michael Turits of Raymond James.

headline: CA, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, May 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: You talked about the renewal portfolio, which was expected to be up more than it was in this quarter. And you said those were -- a lot of those renewals, as I understand it, were renewals you expected but where the natural expiration was next year. And no
componenttext: You talked about the renewal portfolio, which was expected to be up more than it was in this quarter. And you said those were -- a lot of those renewals, as I understand it, were renewals you expected but where the natural expiration was next year. And now you say that comes in the back half of next year. So I think -- first question is why was it that you expected them to close what sounds like 3 to 4 quarters early? And is there anything that you're doing that would have been pulling those renewals forward early?

headline: CA, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, May 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: We track, as you know, Mike, every transaction over a certain size. And what we've seen over the 5 years we've been doing it is we get a certain percentage of dollar statement that is done early, not because we're pulling it forward as those customers ten
componenttext: We track, as you know, Mike, every transaction over a certain size. And what we've seen over the 5 years we've been doing it is we get a certain percentage of dollar statement that is done early, not because we're pulling it forward as those customers tend to want to do it forward for the reasons Mike talked about. They view it as our impending event as opposed to their impending event. This quarter happened to just be a light quarter, where there wasn't as much of a drive towards that behavior, and there were 1 or 2 that we said no to. As predominance flows though, it was just buck the normal historical pattern more than anything.

headline: CA, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, May 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Walter Pritchard of Citi.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Walter Pritchard of Citi.

headline: CA, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, May 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Rich, I'm wondering if you could talk a little bit about the margin expansion that you're expecting for fiscal '16. That's definitely more than we were modeling, and it sounds like you're making still some changes to sales and it requires you to maybe mak
componenttext: Rich, I'm wondering if you could talk a little bit about the margin expansion that you're expecting for fiscal '16. That's definitely more than we were modeling, and it sounds like you're making still some changes to sales and it requires you to maybe make some investments or at least make it difficult to cut there. On the product side, you're doing some organizational consolidations. So I guess that maybe some of the margin improvements is coming there. But Mike, you seemed to mention kind of the same amount spent on product development as you have in the past. So could you help us understand where we should expect to see that leverage, the 200 basis points?

headline: CA, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, May 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. So if you'll recall, over the last couple of years, we've been rebalancing the company from top to bottom, sales, development, G&A functions. And what you're really seeing now is all that hard work over the last 2 years is now paying off in fewer si
componenttext: Sure. So if you'll recall, over the last couple of years, we've been rebalancing the company from top to bottom, sales, development, G&A functions. And what you're really seeing now is all that hard work over the last 2 years is now paying off in fewer sites, people consolidated, doing things like Agile. On the sales side, what you see is actually more quota carriers. And you'll see even more quota carriers next year, but less layers. And you heard the question earlier on inside sales. It's cheaper. It's faster for us to get to. If you look at it from the G&A functions, we actually came down and we'll come down again. And that's the normal pattern we'll continue to drive to. We're very comfortable with the 39%. And remember, and you'll see it tomorrow in the K, there's $40 million worth of people that left the company that we had to pay for in the last year's number, which comes out of the run rate. And so you pick that up in that year-over-year expansion of margin. And so we really have rebalanced the company, which is how -- why we described you this structure [ph] 2 years ago.

headline: CA, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, May 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Abhey Lamba of Mizuho Securities.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Abhey Lamba of Mizuho Securities.

headline: CA, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, May 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Mike, the product management-level changes seemed too drastic, especially as they're coming into -- coming 2 years into the restructuring. Can you talk a little bit about how you plan to kind of -- number  one, what came about -- what thought process crea
componenttext: Mike, the product management-level changes seemed too drastic, especially as they're coming into -- coming 2 years into the restructuring. Can you talk a little bit about how you plan to kind of -- number  one, what came about -- what thought process created that situation? Number two is how would -- how do you plan to address any issues of the churn at the senior executive level and the impact it may have at the product side, which can take a couple of years to kind of flow through the system?

headline: CA, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, May 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Great question. First of all, the thought process here is, after operating the company for a while and taking a look at the last 2 years and really taking a look at the last 2 quarters and thinking about the velocity that we keep talking about, are we get
componenttext: Great question. First of all, the thought process here is, after operating the company for a while and taking a look at the last 2 years and really taking a look at the last 2 quarters and thinking about the velocity that we keep talking about, are we getting new products and differentiated products to the market as quickly as I would like it to be? And secondly, listening to customers of the kinds of problems that they want us to solve. And most of those problems that they want us to solve have to do with complexity. And what is unique about CA is we truly can go from mobile to mainframe. And when you think of this Application Economy, driving from mobile to mainframe and trying to reduce complexity, I took a look at our organization and it's actually the -- is more complex than I think it should be. In order to -- when we're building products, having the mainframe completely separated from the rest of the eSTG product, it became more difficult to think through holistically solving the problems of our customers. When you take a look at a lot of our growth products, API management, for example, most of the targets of the API management product, the product is opening up the transactional processing of the mainframe. Service Virtualization, one of the most popular use cases of that is virtualizing the mainframe. When it comes to Release Automation, there is as much software being released and changed at a higher velocity on the mainframe as well as the massive amounts of distributed architectures that customers are deploying. So having one person managing all of the products, I think, is an opportunity for us to make sure when we go to a customer, we're going to that customer with one voice. Now it's also a big job, and to have that one person think of all of the products and the nuances of our products and also worry about our platform and the technical platform that's going to be required 1 to 2 years out, I didn't feel that we would be best served by having 1 person do that. So I've had to search out for a CTO now for probably about 1.5 months to 2 months, and I've seen an incredible number of candidates. And as I'm looking through those candidates, I think that we're going to have an opportunity to up our game and up our ability to serve our customers. Now the other thing is underneath that Chief Product Officer is all of our general managers, and they're not changing around. This is a group that is definitely committed to understanding modern software development. And their focus in life is to make sure they're building products that are easy to use, easy to install, easier to sell, try and buy. And I don't see that changing at all going forward. It's more just a -- more of a logical view of listening to customers and positioning ourselves for accelerated growth. Does that answer your question and help you get an understanding for why go through this change?

headline: CA, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, May 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Kirk Materne of Evercore ISI.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Kirk Materne of Evercore ISI.

headline: CA, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, May 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: It's Matt Williams actually on for Kirk. Just one from us. One area that we haven't heard a whole lot about on the call that you guys seem to have a pretty good position on is Security. And I was just wondering if you could provide a little bit of color i
componenttext: It's Matt Williams actually on for Kirk. Just one from us. One area that we haven't heard a whole lot about on the call that you guys seem to have a pretty good position on is Security. And I was just wondering if you could provide a little bit of color in what you're seeing in your Security business, particularly with the Identity and Access Management offerings that you guys have and how that business is performing.

headline: CA, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, May 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. First of all, last quarter, the one that just passed, Q4 was a very strong Security quarter for us. It's up in the high 20s. And no doubt about it, Matt, that is becoming an extraordinarily important technology and it's an important space for us to
componenttext: Sure. First of all, last quarter, the one that just passed, Q4 was a very strong Security quarter for us. It's up in the high 20s. And no doubt about it, Matt, that is becoming an extraordinarily important technology and it's an important space for us to be in. When you think about what has happened over the last 18 months, identities have become the savior for most companies. So the fact that they can understand who's using their systems and who has the authorization to use those systems and understanding privileged identity, that is an absolute superstrong spot for us to be. When it comes to managing identities at volume and at scale, we are by far the #1 player in that space. You go take a look at the industry analyst reports, they constantly hold us out as the volume player for almost every enterprise and vertical. So we feel very good about our Security business. It's an area where we're making some big investments. And at CA World, we'll be launching some additional Security products.

headline: CA, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, May 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: That concludes today's question-and-answer session. I would now like to turn the call back to CEO, Mr. Mike Gregoire, for any further remarks.
componenttext: That concludes today's question-and-answer session. I would now like to turn the call back to CEO, Mr. Mike Gregoire, for any further remarks.

headline: CA, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, May 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, thank you very much and thank you for your time. I know there's a lot of people reporting tonight. But in summary, I would take a look at the quarter and the year as qualitative and quantitative success. From a qualitative perspective, we have a lot
componenttext:
Well, thank you very much and thank you for your time. I know there's a lot of people reporting tonight. But in summary, I would take a look at the quarter and the year as qualitative and quantitative success. From a qualitative perspective, we have a lot of margin expansion, 0.75 points. That's showing the continued efficiency. We had CFFO growth. We returned over 65% of our free cash flow to shareholders. Named account performance and traction is in double digits. We have healthy attach rates to our renewals, and I think that's a big testament to the work that the team has done over the last year to improve our Net Promoter Score. The growth products are both 16% growing year-over-year. And in Q4, most of them were in the high 20s. And we've completed the FY '14 rebalancing actions. So when I take a look at the year in general for FY '15, a lot of qualitative performance that I think the team is really proud of. But at the end of the day, it does have to show up in the quantitative results, and we are very committed to drive growth. So when you think of 2014 [ph], things we have to look forward to, we have 2% points [ph] of margin expansion. We've seen the ES revenue trajectory go from negative to start moving into the positive, EMEA revenue turning to positive in FY '16, a strong renewal portfolio in FY '16 and strong CFFF (sic) [CFFO] growth.
So with that, I want to thank you for your time, and we'll be talking to you in the field. I think we're out on the market talking to a number of investors in a number of shows, and we'll be able to answer your questions more further then. Take care.

Good day, ladies and gentlemen. Welcome to the CA Technologies First Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference call is being recorded. 
I'll now like to turn the conference over Kelsey Turcotte, Vice President of Investor Relations. You may begin

headline: CA, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, and good afternoon, everyone. Welcome to CA Technologies First Quarter Fiscal Year 2016 Earnings Call. Joining me today are Mike Gregoire, our Chief Executive Officer; and Rich Beckert, our Chief Financial Officer. Mike and Rich will offer some
componenttext:
Thank you, and good afternoon, everyone. Welcome to CA Technologies First Quarter Fiscal Year 2016 Earnings Call. Joining me today are Mike Gregoire, our Chief Executive Officer; and Rich Beckert, our Chief Financial Officer. Mike and Rich will offer some prepared remarks and then we will open the call up for Q&A session. 
These prepared comments were previously recorded and this conference call is being broadcast on Thursday, July 23, over this telephone and the Internet. The information shared in this call is effective as of today's date and will not be updated. All content is the property of CA Technologies is protected by U.S. and international copyright law and may not be reproduced or transcribed in any way without the expressed written consent of CA Technologies. We consider your continued participation in this call as consent to a recording. 
During this call, non-GAAP financial measures will be discussed. Reconciliations to the most directly comparable GAAP financial measures are included in our earnings release, which was filed on a Form 8-K earlier today as well as in our supplemental earnings materials, all of which are available on our website at ca.com/invest. 
Today's discussion will include forward-looking statements subject to risks and uncertainties, and actual results could differ materially from these forward-looking statements. Please refer to our SEC filings for a detailed discussion of potential risks. 
Please note that our second quarter quiet period begins at the close of business on September 15, 2015. Let me remind you that all comparisons are year-over-year and in constant currency unless otherwise indicated. 
So with that, let me turn the call over now to Mike

headline: CA, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, and thank you for joining us. We had an encouraging first quarter driven by improved sales execution, strong operating margin performance and continued progress towards achieving our long-term goals. While our overall first quarter total n
componenttext:
Good afternoon, and thank you for joining us. We had an encouraging first quarter driven by improved sales execution, strong operating margin performance and continued progress towards achieving our long-term goals. While our overall first quarter total new sales were down mid-single digits year-over-year, Enterprise Solutions new sales were up low-single digits over the year. This was offset by mainframe new sales, which were down in the high teens. 
The decline in mainframe new sales was in line with our expectations. Mainframe capacity was negatively impacted by both the decline and composition of our Q1 renewal portfolio as well as a renewal with a large North American financial institution that required less capacity following a merger that occurred multiple years ago. That said, our outlook for the Mainframe business remains unchanged as we continue to expect mainframe revenue to be down low-single digits over the medium term, which we believe is in-line with the mainframe market. 
Non-GAAP operating margin was 41% in the quarter as we remain focused on efficient execution and financial discipline. Although I am pleased with the efficiency of the business and encouraged by the improvement in Enterprise new sales, we still have work to do to drive the kind of growth that our company has the potential to achieve. Our recent results only partly capture the traction we are experiencing in the field and the strong market opportunity in front of the company. 
The disruption of traditional business models is clearly accelerating as enterprises across the globe are embracing the Application Economy to drive innovation. CA solutions enable enterprises to capitalize on the opportunities created by this Application Economy, where software is the competitive differentiator and application development is the driver of innovation. Let me provide you with more insight into the progress we're making towards our strategy to deliver differentiated solutions, improve sales execution and increase our velocity. 
First, in product development, we have stated that in order to be a leader in the next generation of software, innovation must be the lifeblood of our company. The recent hiring of Otto Berkes as our new Chief Technology Officer signals our intent to accelerate organic innovation and enrich CA's long-term technology vision. Otto's experience as Chief Technology Officer at HBO and his 18-year tenure at Microsoft, where he was one of the 4 original innovators of Xbox, exemplifies the talent we are attracting that will be critical in helping us achieve our longer-term product development goals. 
I am also very pleased that Ayman Sayed will be joining CA as the Chief Product Officer on August 10. Ayman comes to us from Cisco, where he was the Senior Vice President of Network Operating Systems Technology Group, leading the development of network operating software, in which nearly every Cisco networking product runs. Ayman is a very accomplished executive, who oversaw the vision and engineering direction for Cisco's software strategy. He has experience with Agile software development and pioneered the Internet of Things innovation at Cisco. At CA, he will work closely with Otto to create the best-in-class products. Their teamwork and focus will drive organic technology and product development, which continues to be our priority and help CA's customers gain advantage in the Application Economy. 
To complement our organic road map, we recently enhanced our internal development capabilities with 3 transactions. We characterized 2 of the deals as technology tuck-ins that expand our capabilities in Security and DevOps. The acquisition of Rally, which closed a few weeks ago, represents a more significant investment. By adding Rally's award-winning cloud-based Agile development platform and its transformation consultants and coaches to the fold, CA becomes an industry leader in the fast growing Agile application Life-Cycle Management software market. Importantly, this acquisition also adds product and service capabilities that are highly complementary to our award-winning PPM solution and strengthens CA's existing DevOps leadership. 
With less than 5% customer overlap in our platinum accounts, Rally's, best-of-breed technology and unmatched scalability provides ample opportunity to cross sell into these strategically important accounts as well as cross sell our solutions into their install base. I am confident that Rally is a natural, strategic fit for CA. Our products and go-to-market methods align well, and equally as important, Rally's culture and focus on delivering high-quality solutions mirrors ours. 
To maintain the current momentum, the Rally organization and its leadership team will continue to report to Tim Miller in his new position as General Manager, and over time, will be fully integrated into CA. Later during the call, Rich will discuss rally's impact to our fiscal 2016 guidance. 
Our management cloud solutions experienced success in the quarter and our solutions continue to be recognized for their leadership in the space. For example, in the quarter, CA PPM was designated as a leader in the Gartner Magic Quadrant for IT Project and Portfolio Management software. In addition, during Q1, CA PPM had several high-profile wins such as the competitive replacement with Delta Airlines that is leveraging our technology to automate the vast number of complex business process across a multitude of different internal organizations. Equally impressive was a win with Macy's, which required enterprise-wide PPM to provide a common system of record and process for all business and IT projects. Overall, I'm encouraged by the improved execution during the quarter and I look forward to updating you on integration of Rally and our product road maps through this fiscal year. 
Turning to DevOps. The new release of CA APM 10 and CA UIM 8.3 feature compelling, new user interfaces and analytics to facilitate collaboration in dynamic environments. Specifically, these new integrated solutions dramatically improve the ease of use for IT operations teams by providing the speed and scale organizations need to rapidly deploy new applications, monitor dynamic environments and continuously optimize application quality to ensure superb customer experiences. 
Let me briefly highlight our continued APM success. I am pleased to report that APM's positive momentum has continued in fiscal 2016. In the quarter, the product posted impressive new sales growth of approximately 20%. Our fiscal Q1 release of APM 10 was a highlight in a brief to market new capabilities that accelerate customers' DevOps initiatives. Key patent pending functionality added to APM 10 include: A completely redesigned user interface that enables first level production support personnel to resolve production problems much more effectively; analytics technology designed to reduce the skill level required for troubleshooting; unique time line functionality that quickly correlates performance issues with past app changes. This is differentiated technology that enables DevOps teams to receive recommended fixes in real-time, a must-have in the highly dynamic world of cloud and micro services. 
I am very excited about our continued success in APM and the launch of APM 10. Importantly, customers in the broader market share enthusiasm. For example, just a few weeks ago, CA APM was featured as the #1 APM product by Dow Jones newswire based on the number of customer reviews on crowdsourced review site, IT Central. 
Our security pillar demonstrated consistent execution during the quarter. The need for comprehensive security solutions continues to strengthen worldwide. With the frequency and severity of breaches continuing to impact enterprises across the globe, companies are looking to software firms like CA to provide guidance on how to protect their users and data. 
Leveraging our position within security and application delivery, our API management solutions continue to gain mind share. During the quarter, CA was positioned in the leaders' quadrant of the Gartner Magic Quadrant for Application Services Governance for our API management product. APIs allow customers to modernize existing architectures and connect to hybrid cloud applications and mobile devices, while unlocking the value of data. We are a leader in this fast growing opportunity as we can provide API management solutions to scale and security levels needed for the massive amount of data traversing these newly-created digital platforms. For example, after an extensive evaluation of the top vendors in the API management market, a leader in the peer-to-peer lending FinTech space chose CA's API management for ease of use, flexibility and security profile. We see many API management opportunities like this emerging in the marketplace. 
Now let's turn to the second piece of our strategy: sales execution. During Q1, we saw continuing evidence that our decision to separate platinum accounts from our named and growth accounts, and to specialize sales by product discipline, is yielding results. The highlight for the quarter from a sales perspective was the accelerated new sales growth from our named and growth sales teams. Importantly, participation within these combined customer accounts was broad as every geography grew double digits during Q1. Worldwide, these more seasoned sales teams increased deal counts, improved pipeline conversion rates and improved win rates on a year-over-year basis. Additionally, inside sales demonstrated an impressive performance as the team substantially increased its participation in closing business during the quarter. This is important and exciting progress for our company. It's a key indicator of the value of our products and consistent performance from these customer accounts is critical to the success of our strategy. 
Finally, let me address velocity. While Q1 represents progress towards our long-term goals, we still need to move faster in some areas. Our focus on brand awareness and demand generation are vital to improving CA's velocity. 
Let me briefly highlight a recent success our marketing team has experienced. During the quarter, our digital marketing team won the highest accolade in demand generation marketing, Marketo’s Revvie. Winning this award represents our marketing team's use of next-generation technology to push the status quo and help CA break away from the competition. 
Before I conclude, let me be the first to invite you to CA World 2015 at Mandalay Bay, Las Vegas. CA World '15 is bringing the brightest minds in the Application Economy together. Building off our success from last year, this year's event will showcase several new organically developed solutions that will help our customers develop and manage apps and modern IT infrastructures with confidence in definition economy. I hope you will join me in Las Vegas on November 16 through to November 20. 
On balance, our first quarter results and qualitative indicators reinforce my confidence that our improvement in product quality is resonating with customers. In fact, our global net promoter score improved in all geographies and increased more than 10 points year-over-year. During fiscal 2016, we will build upon our progress by focusing on innovation, execution and speed to compete and win in the Application Economy. 
With that, I will turn the call over to Rich to review our first quarter financials and full year guidance. Thank you.

headline: CA, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Mike. Before we get started with the quarter review, let me remind you that all comparisons are year-over-year and in constant currency unless otherwise indicated. This afternoon, I'm going to focus my comments on the key business drivers and p
componenttext:
Thank you, Mike. Before we get started with the quarter review, let me remind you that all comparisons are year-over-year and in constant currency unless otherwise indicated. This afternoon, I'm going to focus my comments on the key business drivers and performance indicators for the quarter. The balance of our financial details can be found in our supplemental and press release. 
As many of you are aware, the dollar continues to strengthen against most major currencies, which negatively impacts both our results and guidance. Our Q1 total revenue was $977 million and was down 3%. Enterprise Solutions declined 2%, and Mainframe Solutions and Services were each down 3%. Q1 renewals were down in the mid-single digits and down in the low teens as reported. 
As we have previously stated, the year-over-year changes in our renewal bookings can vary on a quarterly basis due to the timing of large transactions. Q1 total new product and capacity sales were down in the mid-single digits and approximately 10% as reported. This is due mainly to headwinds from the renewal portfolio. Renewal yield for the quarter was in the mid-80% range. The lower-than-historical average renewal yield was the result of a large renewal with the North American financial institution that required less capacity following a merger that occurred multiple years back. Excluding this one transaction, our renewal yield was in the mid-90% range. 
We continue to expect fiscal 2016 renewals to be up mid-teens year-over-year as compared to fiscal 2015 and up low-single digits year-over-year, excluding the large system integrator renewal that is expected to close in fiscal 2016. As reported, we expect fiscal 2016 renewals to be up approximately 10% year-over-year as compared to fiscal 2015, including a large system integrator renewal that is expected to close in fiscal 2016. 
Turning to the geographies. We experienced an improvement in new sales in Latin America in spite of the macro headwinds in the region. However, sales in EMEA and North America were down, reflecting both decline and composition of the renewal portfolio in Q1. 
In our Mainframe segment, Q1 mainframe new sales, including new product and capacity, were down high teens in constant currency and down in the mid-to 20% range as reported. Overall, we continue to expect our Mainframe revenue to be down low-single digits over the medium term, which we believe is in-line with the mainframe market. 
Q1 Enterprise Solutions new product sales were up low-single digits in constant currency and down mid-single digits as reported. The improvement in Enterprise Solutions' new product sales was mainly a result of improvement in sales outside our renewal process. 
Services revenue decreased 3% in constant currency and 9% as reported. We expect lower services bookings in fiscal 2015 to be a headwind to fiscal 2016 revenue. Over the long term, we expect Services revenue to decline as we design our products to be easier to install and leverage partners for more service engagements. 
Current revenue backlog was down 3%. Current revenue backlog was impacted by headwinds from a large system integrator expected to be renewed later in fiscal 2016 and lower fiscal 2015 services bookings. As I've said before, consistent year-over-year growth and current revenue backlog is one of the indicators of future revenue growth. Current revenue backlog will likely grow when we demonstrate multiple quarters of new sales growth, while maintaining a low 90% renewal yield. 
Q1 non-GAAP operating margin was 41% and GAAP operating margin was 31%. Segment operating margin in the quarter were 62% from Mainframe Solutions, 14% for Enterprise Solutions and 10% for Services. Q1 non-GAAP tax rate was 29% and our GAAP tax rate was 30%. Q1 non-GAAP diluted earnings per share was $0.64, up 9% year-over-year. Q1 GAAP diluted earnings per share was $0.47, up 15%. 
Our Q1 CFFO was $188 million, up 38%. Single installment cash payments were $37 million and down year-over-year. We ended Q1 with approximately $1.4 billion in net cash. 
During the first quarter, we repurchased 50 million in shares and paid $110 million in dividend. We have $735 million remaining in our original 1 billion share repurchase program. Subsequent to Q1, we drew down $400 million from our $1 billion revolver in conjunction with the close of our acquisition of Rally. 
Now turning to guidance. Guidance is based upon exchange rates in the last day of the preceding quarter, which was June 30, 2015. This includes a partial hedge of operating income. This guidance also includes acquisition of Rally software, which closed earlier this month and assumes no incremental material acquisitions. We expect currency to have a negative impact in our full year fiscal 2016 revenue of approximately 4% at June 30's rates. 
Total revenue is expected to be down 1% to flat in constant currency compared to our previous guidance of down 2% and constant currency. This translates to reported revenue of $4.04 billion to $4.11 billion. We expect a full year GAAP operating margin of 28% compared to our prior expectation of 30% and full year non-GAAP operating margin of 38% compared to our prior expectation of 39%. As previously disclosed, this 1 point decrease in our full year non-GAAP operating margin reflects the Rally acquisition. We expect the majority of this impact to be realized in our fiscal Q2. 
We expect Q2 margins to be negatively impacted by foreign exchange headwinds. And recall, our fiscal Q4 margin was negatively impacted by our Q4 fiscal 2015 severance actions. 
Underlining this guidance, we expect our GAAP and non-GAAP tax rates to be between 28% and 29%, consistent with our prior expectations. Non-GAAP diluted earnings per share is expected to grow 2% to 5%, unchanged from our previous guidance. This translates to reported non-GAAP diluted earnings per share of $2.37 to $2.44. GAAP diluted earnings per share is expected to grow 6% to 10% compared to our prior expectation of 12% to 17% growth. This translates to reported GAAP diluted earnings per share up $1.72 to $1.80. 
At the end of the year, we expect approximately 432 million shares outstanding and a weighted average diluted share count of approximately 436 million shares. Cash flow from operations is expected to increase 2% at 7% in constant currency, consistent with our prior expectation. This translates to reported cash flow from operations of $0.98 million to $1.03 billion. 
And now we will take your questions

headline: CA, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from the line of Raimo Lenschow of Barclays.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from the line of Raimo Lenschow of Barclays.

headline: CA, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: This is Stefan, I'm sitting in for Raimo. Mike, I was wondering if you can talk a little bit about what seems to be a slight change in strategy, perhaps to more aggressively pursue acquisitions again? And then more specifically, can you comment on where y
componenttext: This is Stefan, I'm sitting in for Raimo. Mike, I was wondering if you can talk a little bit about what seems to be a slight change in strategy, perhaps to more aggressively pursue acquisitions again? And then more specifically, can you comment on where you'd expect to see meaningful synergies from Rally over time?

headline: CA, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. I wouldn't say that our strategy has changed at all. We've been consistent for the last 2 years that we have spent between $300 million and $500 million on acquisition, but our #1 focus is organic development. So if you take a look at this particula
componenttext: Sure. I wouldn't say that our strategy has changed at all. We've been consistent for the last 2 years that we have spent between $300 million and $500 million on acquisition, but our #1 focus is organic development. So if you take a look at this particular quarter, we've had an opportunity to accentuate both of those strategies, doing Rally, which is a big acquisition, at $480-plus million and bring on 2 extraordinarily well-respected technologists, Otto Berkes and Ayman Sayed, shows  that we're plauying both offense and defense here. We want to bring in Rally because we see some really deep synergistic opportunities for us, both on the PPM space and on the DevOps space, coupled with the fact that we see almost every customer driving themselves into the Application Economy. The way they're doing that is by building the software and the way they're building software is through Agile. So we see that as a very unique asset that fits very well with our strategy. And when you take a look at the 2 tuck-ins we brought, both of those tuck-ins are going to need a fair amount of organic engineering in order to get them to scale for the kinds of customers that we sell to as well as the kinds of opportunities to expand a little bit more than the standard deviation outside the core of some of the product that we're looking at. In order to do that, you have to have some very experienced technologists, both on the product side and on the pure technology side, to make sure that you're building on the right platform and truly driving product management. And when I take a look at the combination of Otto and Ayman, I think that puts us in the upper class of the ability to do organic development from a leadership perspective. Does that help answer your question?

headline: CA, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, absolutely. And if I could sneak in one more, I believe it's been a few years since the segmentation between the platinum, named and growth accounts. I was wondering if you could provide additional color on the progress? It seems like that took off t
componenttext: Yes, absolutely. And if I could sneak in one more, I believe it's been a few years since the segmentation between the platinum, named and growth accounts. I was wondering if you could provide additional color on the progress? It seems like that took off this quarter and we sort of haven't seen that until this quarter. So if there's anything specifically going on, whether it's a certain product that are doing better than others? And then just on how that coincides, because it seems like there was a decline in Enterprise Solutions' upfront revenue. And I would think that the named and growth accounts, given that they're sort of separate outside the renewal cycle, would actually positively impact that trend, and so any additional color will be super helpful.

headline: CA, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. Very complex question but multitenant. I'll try to answer as distinctly as I possibly can. First of all, it's not any one thing. First, I got to get my hats off to the sales force. We have moved into this year, we said we weren't going to change sal
componenttext: Sure. Very complex question but multitenant. I'll try to answer as distinctly as I possibly can. First of all, it's not any one thing. First, I got to get my hats off to the sales force. We have moved into this year, we said we weren't going to change sales account, we weren't going to go change sales leaders and we weren't going to change the way that we wanted them to sell in the segmentation. So when we walked into this year, we had an experienced sales force on selling to people that they know, understanding how they  buy. And I think that was very important. Secondly, from a product perspective, we have a number of products that are selling very well in the market. I referenced in my call, APM up 20%; API management, we are the #1 player in that space according to industry analysts as well as by financial performance. And then we had a very nice quarter with UIM. So those products sell very well to customers that are not necessarily in the Fortune 50, Fortune 100 and customers that we don't have big relationships with. They are a great entry to those accounts, and I think the combination of both product and our sales force did a really nice job getting into those accounts. The other thing I would remind you off, Stefan, we spent a lot of time, energy and money on marketing. And how do you go find the right people to sell our products, too, and understand what their buying perspectives are? And I think that, that put a lot of air cover and helped make the sales force more productive. The other thing on with the respect to why the upfront revenue didn't happen, I would put into 2 categories and I'll get Rich to comment on it. First of all, our SaaS revenue is increasing. So if you're selling SaaS, you're definitely going to be recognizing that revenue ratably. And then a lot of deals we sold, primarily in APM, those deals went ratably as well. Rich, maybe you have a little bit color on that?

headline: CA, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, Stefan, I think the thing that would help is we actually had a very good attach rate this quarter. Our portfolio that was renewing when you back out that 1 transaction, we actually had a strong quarter. And that puts a lot of traditional products in
componenttext: Yes, Stefan, I think the thing that would help is we actually had a very good attach rate this quarter. Our portfolio that was renewing when you back out that 1 transaction, we actually had a strong quarter. And that puts a lot of traditional products in the reachable nature. And as Mike said, some of the products that did well quarter tended to be, well, PPM and things like that, that are deals you'll see show up overtime. So -- and they will then move from FFO back up into the subscription level.

headline: CA, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Ken Talanian of JP Morgan.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Ken Talanian of JP Morgan.

headline: CA, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: We saw an inkling of growth in the Enterprise Solutions new sales this quarter. And you mentioned -- you just mentioned, you saw a growth in APM, API, UIM during the quarter. But you also said that you; need move faster. I was wondering, what specifically
componenttext: We saw an inkling of growth in the Enterprise Solutions new sales this quarter. And you mentioned -- you just mentioned, you saw a growth in APM, API, UIM during the quarter. But you also said that you; need move faster. I was wondering, what specifically gives you confidence that you can grow enough organically to actually reaccelerate the top line?

headline: CA, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think it comes down to a few things that I kind of referenced in my previous answer. Number 1, I was happy with the sales force, but I still think there's room for improvement. If you want to be a modern sales -- if you want to be a modern sales fo
componenttext: Yes, I think it comes down to a few things that I kind of referenced in my previous answer. Number 1, I was happy with the sales force, but I still think there's room for improvement. If you want to be a modern sales -- if you want to be a modern sales force, a modern sales force generates about 80% of their leads, follow their methodology all day, everyday and does the strategic account planning. When I look across the globe at our sales force, we have pockets of brilliance. We have work to do to help people understand that this is important, and for us, to truly penetrate the kind of customers we want. We have to have a full sales force operating at that level of proficiency, and I think there's some work to be done they are. Secondly, on the product side, we have a number of products that are selling well into both the named and growth accounts as well as back into our platinum accounts. What we need to do is have more products, and I think that's what we look at when we've done some of these tuck-in acquisitions. We accentuate our full portfolio.  Purchasing Rally, I think it's going to be a multiyear investment, where there's lots of tangents of where we can take that particular product when you think about analytics with respect to how that works on the Life Cycle portfolio management. And then lastly, some of the products that we have that are -- we had for a long time, big releases are coming out that we're going to be announcing at CA World. So I feel that we finally have some of our product mojo working. We're putting up new products that people want to buy and that are very competitive in the marketplace. But I think that it's why you asked the question, because I don't think you should rest of that. I think there's a lot more to be done with respect to the markets that we participate in and the constant Forge of the entire company to build products that really matter, I think we have to continue to drive that.

headline: CA, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And as a follow-up to that, you mentioned some new releases of older products. Where would you say you are in sort of turning over that older product portfolio? I mean, how far are you to -- in there, in refreshing all those?
componenttext: Okay. And as a follow-up to that, you mentioned some new releases of older products. Where would you say you are in sort of turning over that older product portfolio? I mean, how far are you to -- in there, in refreshing all those?

headline: CA, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think it -- once again, the long answer to the question, I'll just give you a few highlights. I think in APM, I think we're in the medium to early stages. I think on UIM, I think we have a lot of work to do. A lot of the UIM success has been in selling
componenttext: I think it -- once again, the long answer to the question, I'll just give you a few highlights. I think in APM, I think we're in the medium to early stages. I think on UIM, I think we have a lot of work to do. A lot of the UIM success has been in selling to net new customers. I think getting some of the existing customers that have run the portfolio of products under UIM, we have a particular program in place called Front To that we're driving that. I think we're in the very early stages of that. I think we're in the medium-term stages with our flagship Security products. The latest version of that has been out for about a year and it was a significant change from the previous version. And as we start adding to the existing version right now, I think that's going to be a lot easier and the upgrades are going to be an awful lot easier. So definitely, some room to grow there for sure. And depending on which particular product and which particular segment, I think you're going to get a different answer.

headline: CA, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from John DiFucci of Jefferies.
componenttext: Our next question comes from John DiFucci of Jefferies.

headline: CA, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: That large North American renewable you called out, was that expected in the quarter? Or was it renewed early? We try to model that, I didn't realize it's never perfect, the timing of these things. We just do it based on an average renewal time. But even
componenttext: That large North American renewable you called out, was that expected in the quarter? Or was it renewed early? We try to model that, I didn't realize it's never perfect, the timing of these things. We just do it based on an average renewal time. But even though the renewal portfolio is down, it wasn't down as much as we thought it would be,  so I'm just wondering if that big deal was, that came in early.

headline: CA, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: That was due, John, to be in the back half of the year. And working with a customer, they ask a big account that in Q1. This was a transaction that they had asked us to do it even earlier in previous years when we had said no. They have excess mips after
componenttext: That was due, John, to be in the back half of the year. And working with a customer, they ask a big account that in Q1. This was a transaction that they had asked us to do it even earlier in previous years when we had said no. They have excess mips after working through their consolidations. They actually consolidated 100% of the renewal yield on other ES products, so it was really just overcapacity of MIPS. What it did note, and it goes back to the first question of first caller, it did a little bit to sort though -- we actually had a very good. quarter. So the mid-90s, if you back that out and the tax rate of the ELAs, but to your point, there are -- it's a light leg quarter, though, fro traditionally in Q1 to light quarter. So that does distort your model, but there was a lot of yield out of that. That being said, we had a similar thing, if you recall, maybe 2 years back. And sure enough, later on, they  came back and had to buy incremental MIPS. So when they choose to not have excess capacity, they actually have to pay us more dollars per MIPS. So in the long run, we worked at how that is better for us. We do try to encourage them to keep that model, but sometimes, their own internal pressures cause them to make some shortsighted decisions and we let them do that.

headline: CA, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: This is Jim on for Daniel. Just wondering if you could talk a little bit about the competitive landscape, and specifically on the DevOps side of things, just what kind of opportunities you're seeing with your recent acquisition?
componenttext: This is Jim on for Daniel. Just wondering if you could talk a little bit about the competitive landscape, and specifically on the DevOps side of things, just what kind of opportunities you're seeing with your recent acquisition?

headline: CA, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. But DevOps is really a fragmented business, which I think is storming and forming as we move forward. When you take a look at the whole notion of service virtualization, the ability to create synthetic vesting and the whole option of continuous deli
componenttext: Sure. But DevOps is really a fragmented business, which I think is storming and forming as we move forward. When you take a look at the whole notion of service virtualization, the ability to create synthetic vesting and the whole option of continuous delivery. I think when we look at Agile and you take a look at how we're going to use Rally, that accentuates our position in DevOps, because now we can go directly from product and portfolio management directly into how you build software into driving how you test software, both virtually and through synthetic testing methods, and then driving the whole concept of continuous improvement. Now when you take a look at all that, there's still more things that need to be built in the context with DevOps, and the driving factor is this is speed. As companies move into the Application Economy and their primary deployment mechanism is mobile devices, the trying to build net new apps is decreasing at a pace that I don't think anybody has really understood or taken into an account. And as we start thinking about that problem set, it gives us a lot of opportunity to continue to build on our portfolio. Now when we're talking about competitive competitors, we see most of our competition coming from point competitors that can't stitch together a full DevOps strategy and a full DevOps mission. And we have a whole division built in on that because we think that we're still in early days and there's a lot of innovation that still needs to be built to make that as seamless as possible. Is that helpful?

headline: CA, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, very helpful.
componenttext: Yes, very helpful.

componenttext: Sure. I think what we see today, just now, the products are definitely better and definitely more competitive. I think the marketing is more crisp, more targeted and more focused. I think the sales force understands their mission better and we have a higher percentage of sales professionals that really get what selling is in a modern IT environment. The days of chasing elephants and buying a steak and a bottle of wine and expecting somebody to give you a 5-year perpetual license contract, they're dead. And I think that our sales forces have migrated into a much more collaborative, much more product knowledge-based selling and our targeting is definitely improve. So when I take a look at this statistics and how to measure the sales force, I see up until the right size movement. Not perfect by any stretch of the imagination, but definitely better than it was last year.

As far as how the market goes, we think the market is shrinking, at 1% or 2%. And where we usually make gains is when there's any kind of consolidations going on. We're tended to be one of 2 stable providers that are still investing in pure R&D into the mainframe, but we come across as a very stable and committed vendor and partner to that platform, which may be you're if you're looking at that business, you have something that you want to add?

componenttext: Yes. I mean, because I said across the deal from that 1 provider, there's nothing to do with that leaving the platform. That was just 2 companies that together had too much capacity. As far as our ability to look through our installed base, it hasn't changed as recently as last month, with the pricer who maintains that for me. And Michael, there's no change in the very, very low end. Those guys continue to drift away at 1% or 2% a year. At the very, very high end, those guys are growing their MIPS double digits and that offsets that low and disappearing. So I don't see anything really changing other than the fact that there is more of a blur between what is -- what you call mainframe and what's just up in the cloud. But at the back end of it, it's still a mainframe journey.
